title: RL31284
content: The No Child Left Behind Act of 2001 (NCLB) extended and amended the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA). Major features include implementing standards-based assessments in reading, mathematics, and science, providing grants for assessment development, requiring participation in National Assessment of Educational Progress tests, and applying adequate yearly progress standards. The No Child Left Behind Act of 2001 set goals for student achievement, consequences for schools that fail to meet standards, modified funding formulas to target high-poverty areas, required paraprofessionals to have higher education, initiated new reading programs, consolidated teacher programs into state grants, and mandated teachers to be "highly qualified." The No Child Left Behind Act of 2001 made changes to funding formulas, required higher education for paraprofessionals, initiated new reading programs, and mandated teachers to be "highly qualified." Additionally, federal support for public school choice was expanded, programs were consolidated into state grants for technology integration and bilingual education, and the 21st Century Community Learning Center program was converted into a formula grant with a focus on after-school activities. The No Child Left Behind Act of 2001 introduced changes to funding, required higher education for paraprofessionals, implemented new reading programs, and mandated teachers to be "highly qualified." It also expanded federal support for public school choice, consolidated programs into state grants for technology integration and bilingual education, and transformed the 21st Century Community Learning Center program into a formula grant focusing on after-school activities. The NCLB compared major features and provisions with previous laws for increased accountability in pupil outcomes and pest management in schools, as well as aggregate performance bonuses or sanctions for states.
